snippet: The principle of Pashtunwali, a code of conduct that stresses fairness and gives guest privileges even to enemies, is being lost after decades of war.
abstract: Spate of so-called infiltrator attacks both by and against Taliban in Afghanistan, where attackers will gain confidence of their victims before killing them, is viewed by many Afghans as violation of Patshtunwali code of conduct; attacks are seen as yet another sign of moral decline due to almost four decades of war.

byline.contributor: Najim Rahim contributed reporting from Kunduz, Afghanistan; Ahmad Shakib from Kabul; and Taimoor Shah from Kandahar, Afghanistan.

lead_paragraph: The principle of Pashtunwali, a code of conduct that stresses fairness and gives guest privileges even to enemies, is being lost after decades of war.

headline.main: Afghans See a Collapse of Tradition in a Spate of Devious Attacks
headline.print_headline: Afghans See a Collapse of Tradition in a Spate of Devious Attacks
